statements.sql: select * from `users` where `id` = 1 and `users`.`deleted_at` is null limit 1
select * from `products` where `products`.`id` = '2' and `products`.`deleted_at` is null limit 1
select count(*) as aggregate from `product_descriptions` where `product_id` = '2' and `product_descriptions`.`deleted_at` is null
select * from `product_descriptions` where `product_id` = '2' and `product_descriptions`.`deleted_at` is null limit 10 offset 0

request.request_query:
array:4 [
  "id" => "2"
  "product_id" => "2"
  "active_status" => "1"
  "content" => """
    <h3>Introductions</h3>\r\n
    \r\n
    <p><strong>Gmail</strong> is a free email service provided by Google. In many ways, Gmail is like any other email service: You can <strong>send and receive emails</strong>, <strong>block spam</strong>, create an <strong>address book</strong>, and perform other basic email tasks. But it also has some more unique features that help make it one of the most popular online email services.</p>\r\n
    \r\n
    <p> </p>\r\n
    \r\n
    <h3>Google accounts</h3>\r\n
    \r\n
    <p>Creating a <strong>Google account</strong> is needed to access <strong>Gmail</strong> because it is just one of the many services offered by Google to registered users. Signing up for a Google account is free and easy, and naming your new <strong>Gmail address</strong> will be a part of the sign-up process. This means whenever you're signed in to Gmail, you are automatically signed in to your Google account. You'll be able to easily access other Google services like <strong>Google Docs</strong>, <strong>Calendar</strong>, and<strong> YouTube</strong>.</p>
    """
]
